The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. The most promising approach is to reconstruct quantum theory from a set of axioms. The most promising candidates for the axioms are those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The present paper provides a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory that is independent of any analytical structure. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been enigmatic, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan evolved from a free-living cnidarian and that the extreme degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by a reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some Hv1 residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. The challenge is exacerbated by the fact that the optimum growing temperature for maize is close to the current global mean temperature. We show that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability that the world’s major maize-exporting countries have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. Our findings also highlight the importance of considering the impact of climate change on the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices, which affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty. This is especially true in the context of the current food price crisis.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the causes and consequences of their diversity. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of using DNA metabarcoding to identify species in complex assemblages and the need to consider the potential consequences of trophic categorization. These findings have implications for understanding the causes and consequences of the diversity of large herbivores in a world of limited resources. (Read more)

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show a worldwide distribution of plastic on the surface of the open ocean, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of each of the five subtropical gyres with comparable density. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of floating plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that increase reproductive output. We find that the most important factor is the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy can come from the mother’s own body (allocare) or from external sources (provisioning). We also find that the amount of energy available to the mother is the most important factor in determining the size of the litter. This suggests that the limiting factor is metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for making informed decisions about its management. The COVIDcast API is a data source that provides open access to many of these data, including many that are not available elsewhere. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. The data are available for use by the public. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be a useful resource for the public health community and for researchers and decision makers.

The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanical engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the complexity of the structures. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases to achieve arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized and manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The proposed strategy can also be extended to design structures with complex behaviors under large deformations. In preclinical models, combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression. These findings suggest that ferroptosis inhibition may be a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are widely used in clinical practice, but the mechanisms of their action on vascular remodeling are not well understood. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that this practice has important consequences for sleep. Participants who read an electronic book before bedtime had reduced melatonin levels and were phase-delayed in their circadian clock. These effects were associated with reduced sleep quality and increased daytime sleepiness. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an electronic device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. This study also highlights the need for further research on the effects of electronic devices on sleep and circadian rhythms. The results of this study have important implications for public health.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to trace the evolution of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification. We found that the evolution of beetles is driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These findings suggest that the evolution of beetle diversity is more complex than previously thought. Understanding the factors that drive beetle diversification may help us predict the impacts of beetles on the future evolution of the biosphere.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a sharp boundary. The inner core is a unique part of the Earth that is not affected by plate tectonics. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the core material. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This difference is important for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core.

The present study provides evidence that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This blunted reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased craving. These findings are consistent with the notion that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation is a key factor in the development of addiction.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of modern humans, and understanding its neural basis is a major goal of cognitive neuroscience. Here, we show that the most powerful language models can predict the brain and behavior of humans performing the same language task. This suggests that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are tuned to the statistics of language as predicted by the most powerful contemporary language models. This result provides computationally explicit evidence for a fundamental role of language models in the neural basis of language comprehension. It also raises the question of whether similar models could be used to decode the comprehension of other languages.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the accuracy of the solution is crucial. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of neural networks with great approximation qualities; however, there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which neural networks can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. Our results provide a theoretical foundation for the use of neural networks in scientific computing.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act in time, the spread of misinformation, and the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This article discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that is often cited as evidence for this inability. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and the study has become a canonical example of the phenomenon. The flaws are discussed as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that affects the skin, peripheral nerves, and central nervous system. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis. The former causes the chronic, progressive disease known as Hansen's disease, whereas the latter causes a reactional state known as diffuse lepromatous leprosy and Lucio's phenomenon. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with these two conditions. We also provide evidence that M. lepromatosis is neuropathogenic and that the two species are evolutionarily conserved. The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen in human history is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution remain largely unknown. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time period for understanding the spread of plague across Eurasia. Our results show that plague was already a highly diverse pathogen during this period, and that it underwent a series of evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. We also show that plague spread rapidly across Eurasia during this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. Together, these data provide a more complete picture of plague’s early evolution and ecology. (Read more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. The hypothesis that life began with the evolution of RNA molecules is one of the most popular and widely studied theories. In vitro evolution is a powerful technique that can be used to improve the activity of RNA molecules. Here, we describe the use of in vitro evolution to improve an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world hypothesis.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The ability of fungi to sense and respond to copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is less clear. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. These findings have implications for the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interactions of fungi with their environment. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes and different mechanisms. The identification of disease mechanisms is crucial for developing therapeutics. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-derived astrocytes from living patients, enabling high-throughput screening of therapeutics. This study will benefit ALS patients worldwide.

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group Pygostylia is a major lineage that has been hypothesized to have played a key role in the evolution of the modern avian body plan. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments. In some vertebrates, the absorption spectrum is modified by the presence of proteins that bind the pigments. These proteins are called color-modifying proteins. In this study, we describe a new class of color-modifying proteins in frogs and toads. These proteins bind biliverdin, the pigment that is the precursor of the blue molecule, called biliverdin. The presence of these proteins in frogs and toads is a recurrent event in vertebrate evolution, and it is responsible for the blue-green color of their bones and other tissues. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is widespread in vertebrates. Chlorosis is responsible for the blue-green color of the bones of frogs and toads, and it provides the physiological basis for crypsis in green foliage even under near-infrared light.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs) are key regulators of the tumor microenvironment. ALKBH5 expression is increased in human breast cancer, and ALKBH5 inhibition decreases the proportion of BCSCs in vitro and in vivo. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in the tumor microenvironment promotes the development of BCSCs, which may be a therapeutic target in breast cancer. The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness

The dates show that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the net effect is uncertain because of the complex interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, through fire suppression, can reduce fire activity and mitigate warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. Chitin is synthesized by the host and released into the symbiotic crypts only at night, when the bacteria are most active. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions in which the symbionts thrive. This study provides a mechanistic link between the provision of nutrients and the regulation of the activities of symbiotic microbes. It also suggests that other hosts may use this strategy to regulate the activities of their symbionts. (Read more)

The study of text data has become a central part of many fields, from social science to medicine. However, the analysis of text data is often difficult because of the complexity of the data and the lack of tools to analyze it. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and word embedding, and it is flexible enough to be applied to many domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the world around us.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague, which is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It also provides a new method for studying the history of disease outbreaks, which can be applied to other diseases

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. The disease is caused by a densovirus that has spread rapidly across the Pacific Coast of North America. The present study provides evidence that the densovirus is the causative agent of the disease. The virus was detected in tissues of symptomatic asteroids as early as 1 wk after infection and was associated with the disease throughout the course of the experiment. The virus was also detected in plankton, sediments, and in nonasteroid echinoderms, suggesting that it can spread over long distances. The findings provide strong evidence that the densovirus is the agent responsible for the mass mortalities of asteroids on the Pacific Coast.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the history of Madagascar. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production and mitigate risks. Current systems rely on satellite imagery, crop models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized the information provided by crop experts. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which has been collecting expert assessments of crop status for decades, can be used to build a continuous and probabilistic measure of crop status. This allows us to monitor crop status and predict crop yields earlier and more accurately than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of leveraging the wisdom of the crowds to improve agricultural monitoring. This is particularly relevant in the context of climate change, where early detection of anomalies is critical to mitigate their impact. Our findings have implications for the agricultural sector, as well as for the broader field of crowdsourcing.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing and may help to explain the emergence of language as a uniquely human ability.

The soil is a major carbon sink, but the response of soil respiration to climate change is poorly understood. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotes. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle is still debated. Here, we present a model of the molecular evolution of the plastid genome during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the molecular signature of the transition to obligate parasitism is not a single event but rather a gradual process. This model can be applied to other transitions in the history of life.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Like the naturally formed quasicrystals found in the Khatyrka meteorite and experimental shock syntheses of quasicrystals, the anthropogenic quasicrystals in red trinitite demonstrate that transient extreme pressure–temperature conditions are suitable for the synthesis of quasicrystals and for the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster proteins, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the roles of ASK1 in glial cells in neuroinflammation remain unclear. Here, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a CX3CR1CreER system to generate microglia-specific ASK1 knockout mice. This system allows for the conditional deletion of ASK1 in microglia and provides a useful tool for studying the roles of ASK1 in microglia in neuroinflammation. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest period on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in recent decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased, and we conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that created the 2012–2014 drought. The increase in the probability of warm–dry conditions is likely to continue as global warming proceeds. The 2012–2014 drought is a stark example of the human and ecological impacts that can result from warm and dry conditions. The fact that the probability of such conditions has increased in recent decades suggests that the probability of future droughts has also increased. This conclusion is consistent with the fact that the 2012–2014 drought was the most extreme drought in California in the past century. We therefore conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of drought.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and opens up a new avenue for the development of behavioral interventions. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent study of the effects of real news video content on the physiological responses of 1,000 participants. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. This negativity bias is particularly pronounced in the United States, where it is associated with a tendency to seek out more negative news content. The results also show that individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is considerable. This variation is associated with a number of factors, including political ideology, personality, and the country in which the participant lives. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.” They also suggest that there may be reason to consider the possibility that the content of news around the world is more positive than it appears.

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 (p.R304W) associated with bleeding diathesis, and in ORAI1 (p.P245L), associated with congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a noncell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and demonstrated that this protein inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic and many of them were small. The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but it is difficult to study because of the small number of viral genomes available. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) and show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the rate of substitution is an order of magnitude lower than previously estimated. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. It also shows that viruses have been infecting humans for a long time. This is important because it suggests that the immune system has been exposed to B19V for a long time, and that B19V may have evolved to evade the immune system for a long time. This may help explain why B19V is still a common pathogen. This study also shows that ancient viral sequences can be used to date the origin of a virus. The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. The results also show how the chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why one substrate is able to react, while another is not. These results demonstrate the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is delivered to the squid’s symbiotic crypts at dusk, when the bacteria are most vulnerable. The glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn use the products of this catabolism to enhance the growth of the symbiosis. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia, and its origin from bats and spread to humans is a major public health concern. To better understand how MERS-CoV infects humans, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the spike (S) glycoproteins. The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large share of obesity and diet-related disease. The cell surface proteome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. Addition of a potent MEK inhibitor that blocks MAPK signaling brings each oncogene-induced surfaceome back to a common state reflecting the strong dependence of the oncogene on the MAPK pathway to propagate signaling. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or overall turnout. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Vote-by-mail is not a panacea for all problems in election administration, but it is a useful tool in the toolbox.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to millions of deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to spread rapidly through the population, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis for the spread of SARS-CoV-2 and may lead to the development of new therapeutics.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The problem of selective inference is that having mined a set of data to find potential associations, how do we properly assess the strength of these associations? The fact that we have “cherry-picked”—searched for the strongest associations—means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see. This problem becomes more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for making inferences from data that is large and complex, and to provide tools for doing so that are transparent and easy to use. The hope is that this will lead to more responsible and useful reporting of results from complex statistical analyses.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although many attempts have been made to generate ECs from pluripotent stem cells and nonvascular cells, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce vascular ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone induces the development of vascular ECs from human fibroblasts. Our study provides a promising approach for the generation of vascular ECs and the development of vascular networks for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, ETV2-induced vascular ECs can be used as a model for studying the development of vascular ECs. These findings will contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for vascular disorders. (Show more)

These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. They also provide a model system for studying the physiological function of ligand-activated RTKs in vivo. The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been well established. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. Here, we demonstrate that YAP/TAZ activation by disturbed flow promotes the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of endothelial phenotypes and the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also provides a rationale for the use of YAP/TAZ inhibitors in the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that had to be extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examine geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse ecosystems on Earth. However, they are also among the most threatened. The ongoing mass bleaching events are pushing coral reefs to the brink of collapse. Our study provides insights into the underlying causes of the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. We show that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host increases during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Energy limitation and altered symbiotic nutrient cycling are thus key factors in the early heat stress response, directly contributing to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis. Interpreting the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions provides a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In all animals, the epithelium is also the site of tumorigenesis. Here, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and some patients relapse after treatment. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft mice, which may be due to the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. Finally, we found that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize and reengraft mice. Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis highlights the importance of freshwater fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and sustainable development. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both food security and species diversity. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This finding suggests that the molecular mechanisms that mediate regeneration in the adult CNS are distinct from those that mediate regeneration in the developing CNS. We also identify a form of regeneration that is triggered by sensory activity and is dependent on the DLK-1/DLK signaling pathway. This finding suggests that the molecular mechanisms that mediate DLK-independent regeneration in the adult CNS are distinct from those that mediate DLK-dependent regeneration in the developing CNS. These findings provide a foundation for future studies aimed at understanding the molecular mechanisms that mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. They also suggest that the adult CNS retains a regenerative capacity that can be activated by sensory activity.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during meiosis. It is essential for the formation of genetic diversity in sexually reproducing organisms. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a fundamental property of genomes, and its study has been a major focus of research in the field of molecular genetics. Here, we describe the detailed pattern of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is highly conserved across species, suggesting that the general pattern of recombination described here may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This study provides a detailed view of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant, which will be useful for understanding the evolution of recombination in other plants and for understanding the genetic basis of traits that depend on recombination, such as cancer and genetic diseases.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of distributed neuronal populations. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in the field of functional neuroimaging. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We observed that the dominant metabolic RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and early PD patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This approach may be useful for the early diagnosis of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is present on all mRNAs that are translated in the cell. The 5′ cap structure is also important for mRNA export from the nucleus. The 5′ cap structure is also present on some RNAs that are not translated, such as rRNA and tRNA. Here we describe a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-RNA is present on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of NAD-RNA on nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs suggests that NAD+ may play a role in the regulation of gene expression in the nucleus. The discovery of NAD-RNA on mitochondrial mRNAs suggests that NAD+ may play a role in the regulation of mitochondrial gene expression.

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We studied DNA methylation differences in whole blood and monocytes from people with diabetes during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and compared them with controls from the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications Study (EDIC) 10 y later. We found that DNA methylation differences persisted at specific loci associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a resource for future studies of epigenetic regulation of gene expression in diabetes complications. This resource includes DNA methylation profiles of whole blood and monocytes from people with diabetes during the DCCT and controls from the EDIC Study. The resource also includes a list of differentially methylated genes and genes associated with glycemia. The resource is available at: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE68582. This resource is expected to be useful for researchers studying diabetes complications. It will also be useful for researchers studying epigenetic regulation of gene expression in diabetes complications.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is complex and involves multiple factors. In the last few years, the existence of a bidirectional communication between the brain and the gut has been suggested. This study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects and that this alteration is associated with psychological symptoms of the disorder. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also suggests that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of gut leakiness and in the maintenance of the psychological symptoms of alcohol dependence. This hypothesis should be tested in future studies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The tomato is a model system for studying the biosynthesis of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in plants. The production of VOCs is essential for the development of fruit aroma, and the identification of the biosynthetic pathways is important for understanding the regulation of fruit aroma and for improving the flavor of the crop. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous VOCs in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous VOCs. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of VOCs in tomato fruit and will be of interest to researchers studying the biosynthesis of VOCs in other fruit crops. We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. We demonstrate that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance curves of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined impacts of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of climate change on the functioning of ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub for navigation, and its neurons are thought to encode information about the local environment, including the animal’s position and heading. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC neurons is still largely unknown. Here, we used a miniaturized, portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that neurons encoding information about the local environment are strongly coupled among themselves, but weakly coupled to other cell types. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons and will be useful for understanding the neural computations underlying navigation. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. This may have important implications for the understanding of the role of ether lipids in inflammation and other diseases. Our results also suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis and alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity are important targets for the treatment of inflammation.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the idea that information is stored in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features and the integration of information over time. It also provides a framework for understanding the neural basis of language processing. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We show that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to large water bodies, especially in coastal areas. Our findings reveal that small watersheds can be a major source of nutrients to valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work highlights the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and provides a framework for identifying and managing nutrient sources in large water bodies. Our findings have implications for the management of coastal ecosystems worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is capable of providing work only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “rare event” dynamics of statistical physics, and it is a consequence of the fact that the environment is able to provide work only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. Our results suggest that the rare event dynamics of chemical networks may be a general feature of many systems that are driven by environmental constraints.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event can be linked to a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. This study provides a key step in understanding the history of abrupt climate change and its impact on the evolution of life on Earth.

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent it inherits from. In species with multiple loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent it inherits from, but the sex of the parent is determined by the sex of the parent it inherits from, and so on. This process can result in a variety of genotypes and phenotypes, including two sexes, multiple sexes, and multiple phenotypes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple loci on the secondary sexual characteristics of a fish species, where two female-determining alleles interact to produce four possible genotypes and phenotypes. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles and genotypes in sex determination. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists and that siphonophore specialists can evolve into specialists on other prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. This work contributes to the understanding of the role of predators in the functioning of ecosystems. It also helps to improve our ability to predict the consequences of environmental changes on the structure and functioning of ecosystems.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record for the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse and fragmentary, and the origin of the distinctive complex of features in the radial carpometacarpal joints is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Read more)
